Swallows nervously and seems somewhat insincere or performative in his attempt to connect (holds a sly smile while Bretton glares at him)
Takes in the new view of his office and appears settled in, working late into the night at his desk, showing diligence and dedication.
Engages in conversation with Gordon Gekko, showing some awareness of risks in financials but seems unaware of the full extent of the trap Gekko sets ('What bad position?').
Is being manipulated into a false sense of due diligence by Gekko, who advises staged hard work to trick him.
Quickly follows Bretton Woods on a challenging motorcycle ride through a restricted forest trail, showing physical capability and confidence.
Collects himself to share a thoughtful financial idea despite the informal and high-adrenaline setting.
Demonstrates insight by identifying undervalued insurance companies as investment opportunities when others are avoiding them.
Asks specific and relevant questions about current financial positions (shorts in financials), showing understanding of market context.
Fails to immediately get a reaction from Bretton when proposing his idea, suggesting some hesitation or lack of full confidence at that moment.
Responds thoughtfully with a personal definition of being rich, emphasizing love over money, showing emotional intelligence but is met with boos, revealing social miscalculation.
Becomes visibly uncomfortable and loses his smile when Gordon Gekko mentions his daughter's financial health being in Bretton's hands, indicating possible unease or insecurity under pressure.
Gets out of bed to presumably start his day despite apparent worry and lack of sleep.
Acknowledges his insomnia and emotional stress but does not let it completely overwhelm him, continuing with his routine by going to the office.
Forgets his wallet on the bed, which indicates a momentary lapse in attention to detail.
Keeps composed and tries to reassure Winnie by telling her to go back to sleep despite his own visible struggle.
Shows no explicit display of proactive problem-solving or strategic action in this excerpt; mainly internal and emotional.
Engages Gordon Gekko in a direct, challenging conversation, showing persistence and emotional insight.
Listens carefully to Gordon's story and actively tries to piece together the scheme being described, showing analytical thinking.
Turns away when Gordon criticizes him, indicating some emotional vulnerability or uncertainty.
Shouts emotionally at Gordon about personal relationships, which might indicate impulsiveness rather than measured competence.
Carefully reviews and carries detailed trade printouts from Oleg, showing diligence and attention to detail.
Analyzes complex financial relations, connects multiple characters and their actions intelligently (e.g., fallout between Bretton, Gordon, and Winnie's father).
Explains the situation clearly to Winnie, demonstrating confidence and understanding.
Presses on with facts even as Winnie shows emotional distress, showing persistence but possibly lacking emotional sensitivity.
